title: Fixing non-Cartesian flash bounding box

content.raw:
Here's an example script and image.


```
#!python

import numpy as np
import yt
ds = yt.load("starwind_hdf5_plt_cnt_0000")
dd = ds.all_data()
print dd["cell_volume"].sum(dtype="float64")
print ds.domain_width[0]**3 * 4/3. * np.pi
print dd["cell_volume"].sum(dtype="float64") / (
        ds.domain_width[0]**3 * 4/3. * np.pi)
s = yt.SlicePlot(ds, 2, "dens")
s.save()
```

![starwind_hdf5_plt_cnt_0000_Slice_phi_dens.png](https://bitbucket.org/repo/BXbAb/images/2242839518-starwind_hdf5_plt_cnt_0000_Slice_phi_dens.png)
content.html:
Here's an example script and image.

import numpy as np
import yt
ds = yt.load("starwind_hdf5_plt_cnt_0000")
dd = ds.all_data()
print dd["cell_volume"].sum(dtype="float64")
print ds.domain_width[0]**3 * 4/3. * np.pi
print dd["cell_volume"].sum(dtype="float64") / (
        ds.domain_width[0]**3 * 4/3. * np.pi)
s = yt.SlicePlot(ds, 2, "dens")
s.save()

content.raw: All tests pass. Good job!
content.html: All tests pass. Good job!

content.raw: My only concern is that I would like to verify my previous statement about the size of the bounding box before I approve, since I am not 100% sure I got the factor right. Hoping to be able to do that sometime today.
content.html: My only concern is that I would like to verify my previous statement about the size of the bounding box before I approve, since I am not 100% sure I got the factor right. Hoping to be able to do that sometime today.

content.raw: Fair point.  For what it's worth, in this particular situation it did work.  But I could see this changing in future FLASH versions, and then this would break.
content.html: Fair point. For what it's worth, in this particular situation it did work. But I could see this changing in future FLASH versions, and then this would break.

content.raw:
Ok, so what's happening (which baffles me) is that for the suppressed dimensions in the spherical and cylindrical simulations FLASH is expecting the [yz]min and [yz]max parameters to be in degrees, and multiplies them by pi/180 to get them in radians. This is so even though in the FLASH manual it specifies that suppressed dimensions in curvilinear coordinates are to be interpreted as being integrated over the entire angular range:

http://flash.uchicago.edu/site/flashcode/user_support/flash4_ug_4p22/node14.html#SECTION051110000000000000000

What _actually_ happens in the code is that [yz]min and [yz]max still get multiplied by pi/180, even if the dimensions are suppressed. I think what often happens is that people don't bother to set these for these simulations because they don't have to.

So my suggestion is that for curvilinear coordinates suppressed dimensions should have their extents set to 0 -> pi or 0 -> 2*pi, depending on the coordinate. This way, we get the volume elements correct.
content.html:
Ok, so what's happening (which baffles me) is that for the suppressed dimensions in the spherical and cylindrical simulations FLASH is expecting the [yz]min and [yz]max parameters to be in degrees, and multiplies them by pi/180 to get them in radians. This is so even though in the FLASH manual it specifies that suppressed dimensions in curvilinear coordinates are to be interpreted as being integrated over the entire angular range:

http://flash.uchicago.edu/site/flashcode/user_support/flash4_ug_4p22/node14.html#SECTION051110000000000000000

What actually happens in the code is that [yz]min and [yz]max still get multiplied by pi/180, even if the dimensions are suppressed. I think what often happens is that people don't bother to set these for these simulations because they don't have to.

So my suggestion is that for curvilinear coordinates suppressed dimensions should have their extents set to 0 -> pi or 0 -> 2*pi, depending on the coordinate. This way, we get the volume elements correct.

content.raw: By the way, this is a (harmless) bug in FLASH that needs to be corrected, but we can fix the extents on our end for now.
content.html: By the way, this is a (harmless) bug in FLASH that needs to be corrected, but we can fix the extents on our end for now.

Thanks for looking into this!
content.html:

content.raw:
Hi Luke,

Weird!  Can you try this:

```
#!python
dd = ds.all_data()
print dd["cell_volume"].sum(dtype="float64") / (4./3 *
ds.domain_right_edge[0]**3)
```

and seeing how close to 1.0 it is?
content.html:
Hi Luke,

Weird! Can you try this:

dd = ds.all_data()
print dd["cell_volume"].sum(dtype="float64") / (4./3 *
ds.domain_right_edge[0]**3)

and seeing how close to 1.0 it is?

content.raw: Do you think we ought to change how we're doing it here?  Is there a better diagnostic?
content.html: Do you think we ought to change how we're doing it here? Is there a better diagnostic?

content.raw:
The diagnostic should be anything less than 3D and not Cartesian, in which case we enforce the entire angular range for domain and grid sizes along the suppressed dimensions. 

In the meantime I will work on getting this fixed in FLASH.
content.html:
The diagnostic should be anything less than 3D and not Cartesian, in which case we enforce the entire angular range for domain and grid sizes along the suppressed dimensions.

In the meantime I will work on getting this fixed in FLASH.

content.html: John ZuHone so what should I change before this can go in?

content.raw: What I said above: "So my suggestion is that for curvilinear coordinates suppressed dimensions should have their extents set to 0 -> pi or 0 -> 2*pi, depending on the coordinate. This way, we get the volume elements correct."
content.html: What I said above: "So my suggestion is that for curvilinear coordinates suppressed dimensions should have their extents set to 0 -> pi or 0 -> 2*pi, depending on the coordinate. This way, we get the volume elements correct."

content.raw: I think that's implemented here -- can you double check that I did the change correctly in the diff?
content.html: I think that's implemented here -- can you double check that I did the change correctly in the diff?

content.raw: Sorry, we got our wires crossed here somewhere. The earlier comment I made about nblock[yz] did turn out to be incorrect. I noted this above, but not clearly enough. I'm going to comment in the commit below where it needs to be changed.
content.html: Sorry, we got our wires crossed here somewhere. The earlier comment I made about nblock[yz] did turn out to be incorrect. I noted this above, but not clearly enough. I'm going to comment in the commit below where it needs to be changed.

content.raw: Down here,`gle` and `gre` just need to be reset to 0 -> pi and 0 -> 2*pi, instead of being multiplied by anything. You can't rely on their initial values making any sense.
content.html: Down here,gle and gre just need to be reset to 0 -> pi and 0 -> 2*pi, instead of being multiplied by anything. You can't rely on their initial values making any sense.

description:
As discussed on the mailing list, the left/right edges for non-Cartesian FLASH datasets need adjustment.  I also discovered I was doing the ordering slightly off, so this fixes rtp versus rpt ordering of dimensions.

UPDATE 1: @jzuhone does this look good to you?
